Subjects

arising from: W. Sun et al. Nature https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-023-07011-6 (2024).

Single-cell RNA transcriptome sequencing is a potentially powerful tool for identifying the cellular changes in specific brain circuits that encode long-term memories—that is, the engram. Sun et al.1 used spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) in the mouse basolateral amygdala to uncover “transcriptional signatures in subpopulations of neurons and astrocytes that were memory-specific and persisted for weeks”. We reanalysed the data from their study using widely accepted statistical procedures to account for multiple comparisons2 and for correlated variability of cells derived from the same animal, and identified no significant differentially expressed genes. Our analysis suggests that the data do not support the authors’ claim to have identified cell-type-specific transcriptional signatures of memory in the mouse basolateral amygdala.
